catalogue_raissonne: Murase, Art through a Lifetime, no. 673
creditline: Mary Griggs Burke Collection, Gift of the Mary and Jackson Burke Foundation
description: one of four: dish with high walls and deep scalloped cutouts on each edge, creating dramatic, irregular square shape; textured, beige over glaze against dark brown underglaze; beige over glaze on bottom lightly brushed around bowl; subtle blue vine accents on underside at cutouts
medium: Utsutsugawa ware; glazed stoneware with underglaze slip decorations
text: 現川 Utsutsugawa ware; Mukozuke, literally "dish on the other side" are small dishes placed on the far side of an individual serving tray, behind the soup and rice bowls. Typically, mukozuke are used for special tidbits like marinated fish or vegetables. These mukozuke were produced at Utsutsugawa, a kiln site in Nagasaki named after a nearby river. The kiln specialized in dishes, bowls and incense containers for the tea ceremony.
title: Serving Bowl
